Hi everybody!I'm writing a web application in java (tomcat + jsp/servlets + database  access with postgreSQL).This will be released under the GPL and will eventually be useful as a  framework for other web applications.The application main focus is e-commerce, but not limited to that.I would like to use some form of cryptography to protect data on the  database, but I have some problem figuring out the right approach.Above all, how to store passwords and keys in a shared web server.A problem that I was unable to solve is how to store keys for  encryption/decryption. The api that I'm using is the jca (jdk1.4.x),  and the methods of saving generated keys in keystores fails always. I can serialize the object, and store in the database, but this is not  the most secure approach: this key is needed to decrypt data in the  database, but the database is accessible from the web application.  Assuming that I can find a good and secure place where to store the  database password, I can use a different database with different  user... Argh... to complex and doesn't really solve the problem.Where I can found good documentation about this topic?There is another approach that I would share with the list, something I  thought that can be of bit interest, but probabily wrong and insecure.  After all, I'm a real beginner in secure programming, and I'm here to  learn methods and technics.First of all, I need a secure way to keep database passwords secure, so  I have to keep them separate from the main server. The right approach  could be using a small java bean application that run as normal user  (not tomcat, so it is not shared with other web services or, worst, the  nobody user), that has no shell login, but has a default home directory  or a place where it can hold passwords and keys.The web application could then open an ssl connection (could be done in  the init method at server startup) to get database passwords. The small  bean could check via code signature/rmi/whatever else that the source  is the right one, and handle all the database connections, or give the  db connection/password to the main web application.In this way, we solve the problem of keeping the keys and passwords in  shared directories, and also, an attacker should get root/bean user  account to read data. This is not perfect, and works only if your  provider gives the opportunity to configure a separated java  application (that means, really, another server running in the  background).Any suggestions?Thank you, Mario Torre --  Please avoid sending me Word or PowerPoint attachments. See http://www.fsf.org/philosophy/no-word-attachments.html

Cabot Wealth Advisiory 7/5/07 - TV, Intelligence and More July 5, 2007  Salem, Massachusetts  By Timothy Lutts  -----  There's Nothing On!  The SAT Measures What?  A Company With Predictive Decisioning Software  -----  My wife recently attended a conference in upstate New York and one night found herself back in her hotel room, turning to the television for entertainment.  Now, in our family, real-time network television is a rare event.    Thanks to Replay TV, a one-time competitor of TiVo in the DVR (digital video recorder) business, our favorite shows get recorded on a big hard disk and we watch them when we want, skipping the commercials as we go.  In fact, the only time we watch commercials is during the Super Bowl.  More often, we read.  In any event, there was my wife, in a New York state hotel room, "forced" to choose from a dreadful selection of real-time network TV offerings.  Of course she could have turned it off, but in that dull hotel room in that strange town, she was just searching for a little life, a little humor, a little intelligence.  What she got was bad TV, along with an onslaught of repetitive, often-insulting commercials.  So she called me, and somewhere along the way she asked, "Why do people watch this garbage?  And why do the networks play the same commercials, sometimes several times during the same show?"  I couldn't give her an easy answer, but I did sympathize, and that's really what she wanted.  Soon after, I googled "top ten TV shows," and here's what I found.  America's Got Talent Dateline NBC Deal or No Deal Law and Order N-C-I-S C-S-I Are You Smarter Than a 5th Grader? Two and A Half Men So You Think You Can Dance? C-S-I Miami  I've never seen any of these, which goes to show you how out of touch I am.  But I do know (from reading) that four of them are crime dramas, two are talent searches, two are game shows, one is a sitcom and one is a news magazine that typically focuses on human-interest stories.  Reviewing this list, I'm reminded of the words of HL Mencken, who wrote, "No one in this world, so far as I know, has ever lost money by underestimating the intelligence of the great masses of the plain people."  Then, a few days ago one of my editors commented to me, no doubt after viewing one of the those headlines like "Man Shoots Self in Groin While Attempting To Make Ham Sandwich," "You know, half of Americans are of below average intelligence."  Upon reflection, it's obvious.  And it's statistically inevitable.    The average is near the middle, so half will always be below the average (technically, below the median, but given the very large numbers we're dealing with, there's little difference.)  And if you don't know the difference between mean and median, you probably haven't crammed for an SAT test lately.  The converse, however, does not mean that if you do know the difference you have crammed for the test recently.  That's logic at work.  And the SAT, now that I've brought it up, is not what it used to be.  In 1901 it debuted as the Scholastic Achievement Test, supposedly measuring what students had learned.  In 1941, the name was changed to Scholastic Aptitude Test, supposedly measuring what students were capable of learning, if they had the proper socio-economic advantages.  In 1990, that was changed to Scholastic Assessment Test, supposedly measuring . . . something scholastic?  And in 1994 the name was changed to SAT (the letters officially standing for nothing at all!)  Finally (or, should I say, most recently, because I suspect there are more changes around the corner), in 2005 the name was changed to SAT Reasoning Test, creating a potential redundancy of the word "Test" but only if the first T still stood for Test, which it doesn't.  Reasoning, of course, includes logic, and I like that a lot. I hope they keep that name for a while.  Now, I took the SAT a few decades back.  Two of my kids have taken it and the third is likely to in a couple years.  But something else has changed over the decades besides the name.  In 1995 the yardstick for scoring was adjusted to account for the growing number of kids from less rigorous schools taking the test.  The reason?  The big bulge in the middle of the distribution curve, which had previously been centered at 400, had slipped down into the mid-300s.  To get the mid-point back up, the average verbal score was artificially increased by some 70 points while the average math score had 20-30 points added.  The kids at the top and bottom were barely affected, but the masses of average kids near the middle saw their scores bumped up dramatically.  What does it matter?  Well, a good score helps you get into college.    But is there a correlation between success on the SAT and success in college?  Looking further out, is there correlation between success on the SAT and success in life?  The simple answer is, some, but not a lot.  And more and more colleges are recognizing that; the number of colleges that admit students without regard to test scores now exceeds 400.  But the SAT lives on, and will continue to be here for years to come.  Why?  In part because it's the product of The College Board.    The College Board is a non-profit organization, and while there's no doubt that it works hard to serve the high schools and colleges and families that use it, there's even less doubt - in my mind - that the organization works even harder to ensure its own survival.   ----- ADVERTISEMENT -----  Join Cabot Stock of The Month and get in on the next stock that explodes like these...   * Broadvision-up 670%  * Intuitive Surgical-up 500%  * Yahoo-up 317%  * Amazon.com-up 1,290%  * First Marblehead-up 50%  * International Game Technology-up 110%  * eResearch Technology-up 180%  * NetEase-up 100%  * Expedia-up 114%  * Broadcom-up 97%  * Netflix-up 173%  * Psychiatric Solutions-up 85%  * PetroKazakhstan-up 86%  * Nautilus-up 109%  That's the beauty of Cabot Stock of the Month. It gives us the opportunity to choose the best stock across all sectors, using our proven spectrum system. Sign up today and you'll get immediate access to all current recommendations, along with the free bonus report, Sector of the Year.  To learn more, please visit this link:  http://cabotmail.net/t/208666/13148861/102/0/  -----  Speaking of intelligence, here's a news item I noticed recently.  "A financial services firm in Japan has begun offering lower mortgage interest rates to "intelligent" customers.  GE Consumer Finance Company is giving discounts to people who have good English or computer skills, and work in "high-value" areas such as the law.  The company says more highly skilled workers usually find it easier than others to get jobs and to keep them. They are therefore less likely to become insolvent and default on their home loan.  GE Consumer Finance Company claims this is the first time that mortgage rates have been calculated like this in Japan.  People who have high scores on a test of English proficiency and officially certified IT skills can apply for a small discount.  Those of them who also have certain jobs - such as lawyers, accountants, doctors and financial experts - can obtain further discounts.  If a couple are both employed in the 20 "high-value" professions listed by the company, they will be entitled to a major rate reduction."  It makes sense, and I'm guessing it's illegal to discriminate that way in the U.S.  -----  Getting back to TV, the problem is not just the quality of programming but the quantity of time people spend viewing.  The TV is on for over 7 hours in the average American home, and the average American watches over 4 hours of TV per day.  Worse still, the average American child watches 1,023 hours of TV a year and spends 900 hours in school.  And one thing they're seeing in those hours is commercials.  For broadcast TV, commercials pay the bills, and the advertisers are doing all they can to ensure that the message from those commercials reaches your brain.  But more and more these days, people are working to avoid those commercials by fast-forwarding through them using DVRs.  So NBC recently tested people to see if those commercials had any impact at high-speed.  NBC, you know, wants its advertisers' money even if viewers are watching at fast speeds.  The result, according to a story three days ago in The New York Times, "judging from the biological reactions, the test subjects were just as engaged while watching fast-forwarded advertisements as they were while viewing opening scenes from the NBC show "Heroes" at regular speed."  When it comes to fast-forward advertisements, "the assumption has always been that they have no economic value, that they have no communication value," said Alan Wurtzel, president for research at NBC Universal. "But the fact of the matter is we're learning that they are valuable."  And they're so "valuable" to the financial health of the TV industry that the commercial-skipping DVR that I bought years ago can no longer be bought!  But the problem is not just the commercials.  The problem is that every minute spent watching TV is a minute not being used to reflect, to do something productive, or to interact with other family members.  And the result of all this TV viewing, according to a recent study by the Culture and Media Institute, is that "increased exposure to television correlates with a decline in acceptance of personal responsibility."  Now, it's important to note that the word correlate was used there.    Officially, there's no established causality.  But my sense is that our country has seen a marked decrease in a sense of personal responsibility; that too many people all too easily blame others for their troubles.  And when personal responsibility shrinks, we get a culture that thinks it's okay to act stupid because somebody else will pick up the tab.  ----- Contest -----  Now, there is an investment idea coming here, but first I want to give a reward to a loyal reader who has chosen to read this far.     Who?  It could be you.  Just send me an e-mail right now addressed to contest@cabot.net.  Put "CONTEST" in the subject line.  The sender of the 50th e-mail received (no duplicates, please) will receive his choice of a complimentary one-year subscription to any one of our publications.  The winner's name and state (or country if outside the U.S.) will be announced in the Saturday issue of Cabot Wealth Advisory, so if you want privacy, don't enter.  It's simple.  Do it now.  -----  And now, finally, here we are at today's stock.  It's about intelligence and it's about marketing, and if you understand how important marketing is to the world, you may like this one enough to invest in it.  You know and I know that at every turn, companies are doing their darndest to sell us things.  At Amazon they know what I've bought before and thus know what to sell me next.  And at Netflix they know what movies I've rated highly so they can suggest other movies they think I'd enjoy.  Those two firms have developed specialized software that serves their individual needs, but for most companies, there's off-the-shelf software that works very well, and a lot of it is coming from a company named Chordiant.  Here's what we wrote in a recent issue of Cabot Top Ten Report.  "Chordiant (CHRD) makes customer service and marketing software that helps big companies deal with their customers, so that the goals of both the merchant and the customer are met. Customers include 21st Century Insurance, Bank of Ireland, Banque Populaire, Barclays, Capital One, Covad Communications, Cox Communications, Deutsche Bank, HSBC, Lloyds, MetLife, Nokia, Prudential, Royal Bank of Scotland, Royal Dutch Shell, Time Warner Cable, T-Mobile, UPS and Wachovia. These are huge blue-chip companies, yet Chordiant is still a small company, and growing fast. Historically, the company has had trouble making a profit (its last profitable year was 2004), but after the first quarter's terrific results, CEO Steven R. Springsteel commented that solid profitability was "due to the strong performance in our international business, the acceleration of percentage of completion project implementations in Europe, and greater enablement of our partners resulting in fewer Chordiant resources being required on some project implementations." It sounds good to us. Since then the company has been awarded a patent for "advanced predictive decisioning technology." In other words, the companies using this software sometimes know what you're going to buy before you do! As companies come to depend on this software, Chordiant's future is likely to be consistently profitable, and the realization of that is why the stock is strong today."  Digging deeper, I see that Chordiant has been growing revenues since 2003, and in the latest quarter saw revenues grow 25% from the year before to $32.8 million, while earnings jumped from a penny per share to $0.18 per share.  Analysts are projecting a profit of $0.48 per share this year and $0.72 per share next year.  And the after-tax profit margin was a fat 19.6%.  Trading at 16, it's rather low-priced and thus carries the extra risk of volatility that comes from stocks at this level.   But average trading volume is nearly 500,000 shares per day, and institutional interest is growing.  I'd like it better on a dip to 15, but if it doesn't dip there in the week ahead, 16 may be the best price you'll get.  -----  Editor's note:  To get regular updates on Chordiant, and to get first notice of other hot stocks, consider a no-risk trial subscription to Cabot Top Ten Report. America: The Good Neighbor.  Widespread but only partial news coverage was given recently to a remarkable  editorial broadcast from Toronto by Gordon Sinclair, a Canadian television  commentator. What follows is the full text of his trenchant remarks as  printed in the Congressional Record:  > >>> "This Canadian thinks it is time to speak up for the  > >>> Americans as the most generous and possibly the least  > >>> appreciated people on all the earth.  > >>>  > >>> Germany, Japan and, to a lesser extent, Britain and  > >>> Italy were lifted out of the debris of war by the  > >>> Americans who poured in billions of dollars and  > >>> forgave other billions in debts. None of these  > >>> countries is today paying even the interest on its  > >>> remaining debts to the United States.  > >>>  > >>> When France was in danger of collapsing in 1956,  > >>> it was the Americans who propped it up, and their  > >>> reward was to be insulted and swindled on the streets  > >>> of Paris. I was there. I saw it.  > >>>  > >>> When earthquakes hit distant cities, it is the  > >>> United States that hurries in to help. This spring, 59  > >>> American communities were flattened by tornadoes.  > >>> Nobody helped.  > >>>  > >>> The Marshall Plan and the Truman Policy pumped  > >>> billions of dollars! into discouraged countries. Now  > >>> newspapers in those countries are writing about the  > >>> decadent, warmongering Americans.  > >>>  > >>> I'd like to see just one of those countries that  > >>> is gloating over the erosion of the United States  > >>> dollar build its own airplane. Does any other country  > >>> in the world have a plane to equal the Boeing Jumbo  > >>> Jet, the Lockheed Tri-Star, or the Douglas DC10?  > >>> If so, why don't they fly them? Why do all the  > >>> International lines except Russia fly American Planes?  > >>>  > >>> Why does no other land on earth even consider putting  > >>> a man or woman on the moon? You talk about Japanese  > >>> technocracy, and you get radios. You talk about German  > >>> technocracy, and you get automobiles.  > >>>  > >>> You talk about American technocracy, and you find  > >>> men on the moon -! not once, but several times -  > >>> and safely home again.  > >>>  > >>> You talk about scandals, and the Americans put theirs  > >>> right in the store window for everybody to look at.  > >>> Even their draft-dodgers are not pursued and hounded.  > >>> They are here on our streets, and most of them, unless  > >>> they are breaking Canadian laws, are getting American  > >>> dollars from ma and pa at home to spend here.  > >>>  > >>> When the railways of France, Germany and India  > >>> were breaking down through age, it was the Americans  > >>> who rebuilt them. When the Pennsylvania Railroad and  > >>> the New York Central went broke, nobody loaned them an  > >>> old caboose. Both are still broke.  > >>>  > >>> I can name you 5000 times when the Americans raced  > >>> to the help of other people in trouble. Can you name  > >>> me even one time when someone else raced to the  > >>> Americans in trouble? I don't think there was outside  > >>> help even during the San Francisco earthquake.  > >>>  > >>> Our neighbors have faced it alone, and I'm one  > >>> Canadian who is damned tired of hearing them get  > >>> kicked around. They will come out of this thing with  > >>> their flag high. And when they do, they are entitled  > >>> to thumb their nose at the lands that are gloating  > >>> over their present troubles. I hope Canada is not one of  > >>> those."  > >>>  > >>> Stand proud, America!  > >>>  > >>>  > >>>  > >>> This is one of the best editorials that I have ever  > >>> read regarding the United States. It is nice that  > >>> one man realizes it. I only wish that the rest of the  > >>> world would realize it. We are always blamed for  > >>> everything and never even get a thank you for the  > >>> things we do.  > >>>  > >>> I would hope that each of you would send this to  > >>> as many people as you can and emphasize that they  > >>> should send it to as many of their friends until this  > >>> letter is sent to every person on the web. I am just a  > >>> single American that has read this.  > >>>  > >>> I SURE HOPE THAT A LOT MORE READ IT SOON  God bless us all -Brian  _________________________________________________  IncrediMail - Email has finally evolved - Click Here
